name: bunting
content:
bunting noun
(CLOTH)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ U ] rows of brightly coloured small flags, often in the colours of a country's flag, that are hung across roads or rooms, or above a stage, as decoration for special occasions or political events: The room was decked with festive bunting. Flags and red, white and blue bunting were hung along the main street.
Urs Flueeler/EyeEm/GettyImages
More examplesFewer examplesThe streets were covered with flags and bunting.He stood on a stage decked out in red, white and blue bunting.A giant American flag and bunting graced the porch of his three-story home.

bunting noun
(BIRD)
[ C ] plural bunting or buntings any of several types of small singing bird with a short, wide beak, and usually brownish feathers, found in Europe, Asia, and Africa: They saw lapwings, skylarks and buntings.
Kevin Agar/500px/GettyImages
[ C ] plural bunting or buntings any of several types of small singing bird with a short, wide, pointed beak and brightly coloured feathers on the male bird, found in North and South America: The state bird of Colorado is the lark bunting.
More examplesFewer examplesThe water hole was luminous with birds: fire finches, golden-breasted buntings, herons.Bird species at risk include barn owls, redshank, corn bunting and corncrake.

bunting noun
(BASEBALL)
[ U ] in the game of baseball, an act by the batter of hitting the ball fairly slowly and only a short distance, to put it into a position that causes difficulties for the fielders (= the players on the team whose turn it is to throw and catch the ball), and helps the batter's own team to score: Infielders struggled with Gray's skilful bunting.
More examplesFewer examplesThere was another round of bullpens and pitchers' fielding practice and hitting and bunting.The Japanese play "small ball", a style emphasizing bunting, stealing, sacrifice hitting, and team harmony.
